document.docAuthor: Cocco, Jéssica, Dolibaina, Diego Rodrigo, Casagrande, Mirna Martins, Specht, Alexandre & Foerster, Luís Amilton
document.masterDocTitle: First records of Leucania rawlinsi Adams and L. senescens M ̂ schler (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae) in Brazil: redescription, potential association with Bt maize, larval parasitoids, and spatial and temporal distribution

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: First records of Leucania rawlinsi Adams and L. senescens M ̂ schler (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae) in Brazil: redescription, potential association with Bt maize, larval parasitoids, and spatial and temporal distribution

bibRefCitation.author: Adams, M. S.
bibRefCitation.refString: Adams, M. S. (2001) A revision of the moth genus Leucania Ochsenheimer in the Antilles (Insecta: Lepidoptera: Noctuidae). Annals of Carnegie Museum 70, 179 - 220.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Cirphis latiuscula
;
Hampson, 1905 : 542
[in part], pl. 93, fig. 20.—
Wolcott, 1923 :161
.—
Draudt, 1924 : 167
, pl. 24, row G.—
Schaus, 1940 : 186
[not Herrich-Schäffer, 1868: 148] [ misidentification ].

subSubSection.paragraph:
Leucania rawlinsi Adams, 2001
. 70(3): 186, fig. 1B holotype [dorsal] ( holotype male from Jamaica , St. Andrew Parish, Irishtown deposited in the Private collection of Morton S. Adams), fig. 4C–D male genitalia, fig. 13B female genitalia.—Perez- Gelabert, 2008. 1831: 280.—Núñez & Barro, 2011. 224, in: Núñez & Barro.—Núñez & Barro, 2012. 3384: 47.—Perez- Gelabert, 2015. 8: 73.

Redescription. Head: Mostly dark brown mixed with light caramel scales. Compound eyes hairy. Labial palpi dark brown, short. Antennae filiform, covered by dark and light brown scales dorsally ( Fig. 5 ).

Thorax : Dorsally and ventrally most dark brown mixed with caramel, black, and light scales; metathorax with two grayish black spots at center. Patagia with two light bands dividing dark area into three bands, with distal dark band widest ( Fig. 6 ). Legs with outer surface dark, inner surface light brown, mesotibiae with one pair of distal spurs, metatibiae with two pairs of spurs, one distal and one at middle length.

Dorsal forewing : Length 13–16 mm in males (n = 42), 14–17 mm in females (n = 23). Ground color dark brown, darker over cubitus; veins covered by mixture of white and brown scales; costal area (from costal margin to anterior most part of discal cell) with alternating pattern of dark and white longitudinal stripes; small white dot at end of dis- cal cell; a somewhat triangular caramel patch running from end of discal cell to apex, delimiting posterior dark zone from postdiscal area to outer margin; postdiscal area with row of dark dots over veins; dark brown line between veins from discal area to outer margin; submarginal area with veins covered by caramel scales, extending to fringe ( Figs 1–2 ).

Dorsal hind wing : Almost pure white; costal area suffused by brown scales; submarginal area with veins from Rs to CuA 2 covered by brown scales; small marginal dark brown dots between veins from Rs to CuA 2 ; fringe caramel from apex to CuA 2 , then white ( Figs 1–2 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–4. Adults male (left) and female (right) of species of
Leucania
in dorsal view. 1–2,
L. rawlinsi
, male from Estrada da Graciosa, Morretes, Paraná , Brazil (DD 357), female from Parque Estadual do Guartelá, Tibagi, Paraná , Brazil (DD 350). 3–4,
L. senescens
, male from Parque Estadual de Campos do Jordṳo, Campos do Jordṳo, Sṳo Paulo, Brazil (MZUSP), female from Chapadṳo do Sul, Mato Grosso do Sul, Brazil (EMBRAPA 4372). Scale bar: 10 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Male genitalia : Uncus slender, long, pointed, curved ventrally immediately beyond base, with distance between base and tip longer than length of tegumen. Saccus triangular, slightly shorter than cucullus. Valvae about as long as wide; sacculus rounded, broad basally, narrowed dorsally and bearing 2–3 setae over distal margin; cucullus knob-like, expanded distally, with about 9 spine-like setae on distal margin; sensory plate short; digitus robust, short, pointed, as long as clasper and arranged with it in a C-shaped aspect; clasper narrow, pointed, longer than its base; ampulla digitiform, slender, slightly shorter than clasper. Aedeagus with anterior half of distiphallus broad and rounded, narrowed distally; vesica simple, without appendix, bearing two long, distally curved cornuti ( Fig. 9 ).

Female genitalia : Lamella postvaginalis short, rectangular, fused with tergum VIII; anterior apophysis narrow, as long as posterior apophysis; ductus bursae laterally narrow, gradually membranous towards appendix bursae, as long as corpus bursae; appendix bursae longer than ductus bursae, bent left, coiled, proximal area broad; corpus bursae ovoid, completely membranous, without signum. Papilla analis somewhat triangular, shorter than posterior apophysis, distal margin rounded; posterior apophysis narrow, straight, as long as anterior apophysis ( Fig. 11 ).

Global distribution.
Leucania rawlinsi
has a broad geographical range, from the Antilles ( Barbados , Cuba , Dominica , Dominican Republic , Jamaica—type locality, Puerto Rico , Saint Croix , Saint Lucia , Saint Martin and Saint Vincent ) and Central America to northeastern South America ( Adams 2001 ; Janzen & Hallwachs 2009 ). Specimens deposited in collections confirm this species for Colombia (HT, MZUSP, NHMUK), Venezuela (NHMUK), Trinidad (NHMUK), Ecuador (MGCL, NHMUK, USNM, VOB) and Argentina (CHT).

Distribution in Brazil .
A total of 1,935 Brazilian specimens of
L. rawlinsi
were examined, 1,735 of which were collected in light traps ( Figs 14–16 ).
Leucania rawlinsi
was recorded in all Brazilian regions and biomes including all Brazilian states except for Amapá , Ceará , Paraíba , Pernambuco and Sergipe ( Fig. 13 ). The altitudinal distribution of
L. rawlinsi
in Brazil ranges from sea level to 2,410 m , with ca. 52% (1,012) of the specimens collected below
500 m .
Temporal distribution. Adults were found throughout the year, more frequently from February to August; the peak of abundance for this species is June ( Fig. 14 ).

Taxonomic comments. The only American species of
Leucania
that can be confused with
L. rawlinsi
is
L. subpunctata (Harvey, 1875)
. The latter is known only from the USA and a single specimen from the Bahamas ( Adams 2001 ; Lafontaine & Smith 2010; Poole 2018 ). Although the available data suggest these two species are parapatric, the only diagnostic character that distinguishes them is the presence of an appendix on the vesica of
L. subpunctata
, which is absent in
L. rawlinsi ( Adams 2001 )
.

Analyzed material. BRAZIL— Acre : Mâncio Lima (Parque Nacional da Serra do Divisor, Topo da Serra), 450m , 7–10 , 13. X.2018, 1 ♁, O. Mielke, Casagrande, Dolibaina & Medeiros leg. DZ 40.311 ( DZUP ).
